posts.name: Harrison
posts.cooked:
Hi all.

We are using 2 neos with 25:1 max planetarys for our elevator this year. I would like some help on how to tune the PID for it, I already have it configured and running to setpoints, but since it is under gravity  and it is not tuned well the PID causes the motors to vibrate around their setpoint. (Unfortunately I don’t have a video)

I have tried looking through the Rev starter bot code since they implemented a similar system and it seems to work fine?

I do want to put out there that I am essentially our only trained programmer that also does 90 percent of CAD… while I could go with PID on rio and do feedforward and SYSID I would rather keep this simple and allow me to put my efforts towards my automated scoring/pickup routines/dashboard I made.

Here is the code:

Thanks in advance.
im not super familiar with Sparks, iirc theres no kG but you could use the arbitrary feedforward in setReference as a kG, should make tuning much easier

posts.name: Harrison
posts.cooked:
Ok… How could I tune/do that. Also does anyone know if spark max positional control or MAXmotion would be better?

Keep in mind I have limited experience in PID tuning.

in theory max motion should be better, in terms of tuning kG you want to find the voltage that keeps the elevator in place fighting gravity. you could set the other constants to 0 or use the voltage control and just set a small voltage, until you find the voltage thats enough to fight gravity. you can use that voltage as the arbitrary feedforward and probaly have smaller PlD gains as a result, and reduce oscillation

posts.name: Luca Carvalho
posts.cooked:
Actually, REV says in their documentation to not use the kF gain for position control

IMG_1819 1320×354 97.9 KB

IMG_1819 1320×354 97.9 KB

IMG_1819 1320×354 97.9 KB

This is how my team did it this year.

It can be improved upon but i think its fine if you have a rio2. If you’re using a RIO1. You may want to adjust the conversion factor so its post gear box.

We did use the ElevatorFeedforward in this and it seems to work well in sim.

posts.name: Harrison
posts.cooked: Even if it is just to maintain position under gravity?

posts.name: Luca Carvalho
posts.cooked: Is there any specific reason for sending the setpoint in rotations to the setReference() method? In the method description, it says that it is affected by the conversion factors.

posts.name: Harrison
posts.cooked: I can’t view the code as GitHub is blocked on my school laptop but I will take a look later. We are using a RIO 1

posts.name: Harrison
posts.cooked: Is there any advantage to converting? I just output the encoder value to shuffleboard and record the value at each point I want to be a preset

posts.name: Harrison
posts.cooked: The default is rotations of the motor with no gearing
Honestly i did that to avoid confusion and use the default units from the sparkmax. It resulted in less unit conversion errors IMO.

Then the only thing i would change is i would have the motor relative encoders report back in post-gearbox rotations, which would require you to change the RobotMath functions to ignore it and that might be it

posts.name: Luca Carvalho
posts.cooked:
As @nstrike mentioned, in their code, they used the ElevatorFeedforward class to calculate the feedforward and then pass it to the setReference() method.

This thread discusses the same topic—I believe there’s a lot of confusion around this:

How to use Max Motion with Feedforward Programming

link_counts.title: How to use Max Motion with Feedforward

posts.cooked: Being able to set the height in meters is easier to do; if you convert the motor encoder to report from rotations to meters (not recommended) and use the closed loop controller on the spark max you can run sysid on it to find close constants for your Feedforward and Feedback loops

posts.name: Harrison
posts.cooked: Is this strictly necessary, could I get decent results by doing the arbitrary feed forward set to the voltage that is required to keep it stationary?
I wasnt suggesting to use kF, the arbitrary feedforward is seperate

posts.name: Luca Carvalho
posts.cooked:
You’re right, sorry for the confusion

IMG_1820 1320×1709 276 KB

IMG_1820 1320×1709 276 KB

IMG_1820 1320×1709 276 KB

I had to update my example code bc i realized that it wouldn’t work with sysid since you can’t get the velocity setpoint and the feedforward expects a profiled velocity setpoint.

Sooo i don’t think that you can use MAXMotion with ElevatorFeedforward

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
nstrike:

Sooo i don’t think that you can use MAXMotion with ElevatorFeedforward

You can, but only for the kG term, which is equivalent to just passing a constant to the arbff parameter.

The architecture here is not great and I’d just profile on the RIO.

The architecture here is not great and I’d just profile on the RIO.
